reviews.text: I travel alot for business and pleasure but when Im working am constantly surprised by the different standards of big hotel chains ( the Taipei Hyatt )is not so great but the one in Tokyo was really nice. Central, excellent service, great breakfast buffet, good restaurants and a fantastic cafe that serves outstanding espresso and french pastires (which I avoid but top European quality croissants etc) for those who like to get out quickly in the morning and off to your appointments. Will definitely go back.

They asked how I would like to be addressed when I rang through to anyone, I stuck with "Sir" and asked what paper I would like each morning, along with what time I wanted the morning coffee! reviews.title: PURE HAPPINESS!

reviews.text: In a nation famous for great service, this hotel fails to live up despite charging premium prices. Whoever runs their HR department should be fired. Waiters are either indifferent or incompetent, or both. Staff are not empowered to act on guest complaints. The lobby also lacks any kind of soul, and the rooms feel quite stuffy and old. Highly recommend travelers look instead at ANA Intercontinental, Four Seasons or Ritz Carlton, each of which have incredibly high service levels and make staying in Tokyo the fantastic experience it deserves to be.
reviews.title: Most over-rated hotel in Tokyo?

reviews.text: If you're looking for a beautiful hotel that is centrally located that has an amazing gym then look no further. Everything is at your fingertips - incredible food at the Oak Door (not cheap) and great sushi at Roku Roku and of course the gym (to help you work off all of the food) complete with a lap pool, sauna, steam room and full fitness facilities. A top class hotel.

reviews.text: We have stayed here four times, and loved each stay! The location is convenient, the restaurants are expensive but very good and there is good shopping in Roppongi Hills. We loved the swimming pool and the rooms are comfortable. The service is very friendly and efficient.

reviews.text: First class in all respects and well located. I did think the local phone service charges and the price for breakfast were a bit over the top, but otherwise this hotel is great.

reviews.text: I like this hotel, it's not as new and as glamorous as it used to be when it was built but the service standard is always extremely high and the location is very good.
reviews.title: great service and consistent standards

reviews.text: We recently returned from 9 days at the Grand Hyatt Tokyo. When planning this trip I agonized over the Park Hyatt vs. the Grand Hyatt. My research consistently gave the Park Hyatt a slight edge, but at the very last moment the scale tipped in favor of the Grand Hyatt since their fitness center (but not their pool) was free, and from my memories of Tokyo the Grand was in a better location. We could not be happier with the selection. To all those considering the Park and the Grand Hyatts, I assure that both hotels are gorgeous and top-notch, but there is no comparison when it comes to location. If you are in Tokyo on business and expect to be escorted by local hosts and colleagues, then location may not be an issue. But for individual travelers there for pure exploration and pleasure, the Grand Hyatt wins hands down.
reviews.title: I'm moving in

reviews.text: We visited the beautiful Park Hyatt but were unimpressed by its location. The Park Hyatt is on the west side of Shinjuku where wide streets, new high-rise construction, and raised freeways abound. There is not much street life in the immediate vicinity, and although the area is clean and impressive with futuristic architecture, it also feels dwarfing, sterile and dies at night. The Shinjuku train/subway station is not particularly close if you plan on taking this kind of transportation daily to venture out and see Tokyo (although I understand the hotel provides a shuttle to the station, but that adds another step to your day). The neighborhood (if it can be called that) is purely business and government related.
reviews.title: Love the Grand Hyatt!!!

reviews.text: By contrast, the Grand Hyatt is in the very heart of what's happening. It is part of a relatively new complex called Roppongi Hills, located in the lively Roppongi area. The hotel is virtually attached to the Roppongi subway station, and is surrounded on all sides by interesting streets and alleyways to explore. In addition to the countless restaurants of all types and price ranges in the Roppongi Hills complex itself and on the main streets, the surrounding neighborhoods, especially the winding, small side streets, are teeming with all the character and charm of modern Tokyo. The small side streets are packed with residential buildings mixed in with (they must have no zoning laws) shops, neighborhood eateries, pastry shops, sake bars, night clubs, live band venues, Parisian style cafes, Italian mini-bistros, sushi restaurants, etc. All this and the electric buzz of Tokyo is right outside your door at the Grand Hyatt. Roppongi Hills also houses an art museum/gallery, a 360 degree panoramic view deck from the 54th floor of the Mori Tower building, and an upscale labyrinth of a shopping mall with interesting architectural angles, natural light, and an open, airy feel.
reviews.title: Perfect
Great stay!
reviews.text: The Grand Hyatt itself is perfection. The decor/style is minimalist chic and modern, but is far from cold and austere, with abundant rich dark wood, green granite, natural materials, and super-friendly service. The service was flawless. We used the concierge every day and never had to wait for their availability. They made prompt arrangements, followed up without our asking with additional research and recommendations, and printed customized mini maps to direct us. All staff members we encountered spoke English, and were not only attentive, gracious, and eager to please, but they were perfectionists. We joined Hyatt's Gold Passport before going, which entitled us to free coffee delivered to our room every morning (this is worth a lot, as coffee in Tokyo is expensive, but thankfully delicious). All of our room service orders, including our daily coffee, were delivered to our room at precisely the time we designated. We noticed a few times that they arrived a few seconds early and waited in the hallway until the right time before ringing the doorbell. Service was this precise every day, without fail. Japan is a no-tip country, so it's remarkable that this superlative service comes without expectation of a tip.

The hotel is designed to make your spirit soar. The hallways to the guestrooms are broad, uncluttered and richly finished. You will never see housekeeping carts in these hallways. I don't think they use them. Our large room was filled with deep, rich wood, which is also carried into the bathroom. The travertine/marble encased walk-in shower is also where the deep soaking tub is located, so you can imagine the glassed-off shower/tub area of the bathroom is enormous. High ceilings are carried throughout, from the hallway outside, to the room and bathroom. They've paid exquisite attention to every detail, from the linens to the automatic shades, toiletries and travel necessities boxed and arranged in the bathroom drawer, easy and free high speed internet access, layers of lighting, bathrobes, slippers and yukatas (like a simplified cotton kimono) for your use. We were on the 19th floor so we also had wonderful views.
reviews.title: Great hotel

reviews.text: I won't repeat what others have wrote so here's some new information: I visited (didnt stay) the 4 seasons maronouchi, mandarin oriental, park hyatt (stayed 1 night) and here's the deal: You cant beat the grand hyatt. I am not sure if the rooms are better at the other hotels since I didnt see them but the location and lobby of the hyatt can't be beat. It's so spacious and the MO and 4S seemed very small. It's as if the only thing on the ground floor is the front desk. The GH has many places to eat and is attached to the mall which means there are at least 30 different places to eat, amazing. I highly recommend the high end japanese restaurant on the 4th (or 6th) floor of the hotel connecting the mall (Shinbou may be the name). I had lobster sashimi which is nearly impossible to find in the US. The tail was filled with meat and was separated from the body but the lobster kept moving it's eyes and legs while on ice. Also had fugu (the real deal costs at least $200, mine US$300 for one person at kuromonto near this hotel (5 min taxi). This restaurant serves fugu 5-7 different ways so it's a good way to try different preparations (and yes, one is sashimi). It was very good but not excellent but it's the fish not the restaurant's issue. Cool front entrance, somewhat nice interior. The park hyatt has much fewer restaurants but an amazing bar that is worth visiting for a drink due to the view from the 41st floor with glass walls on 3 sides.
reviews.title: Visited many of the top hotels in Tokyo

reviews.text: My room was enormous. The design was very minimal without being cheap. Hardwood Floors, Japanese soaking tub, a large comfortable bed and the mult-talented japanese toilet were all nice features that enhanced my sleep and stay. I stayed here five days because my favorite DJ was playing around the corner. I will definitely stay here again in the future.

reviews.text: There's plenty of choice in Tokyo: Imperial & Okura if you like trad Japanese style, and then Mandarin & Peninsula are probably the pick of the intl chains. But I always stay at the Hyatt in Roppongi because the rooms are perfect, black-out curtains, huge beds, deep bath and walk-in shower, great choice of restaurants & bars and generally good Hyatt service. Plus the Hyatt Gold Passport scheme is one of the best for redeeming points into free stays when I want to extend a business trip into a weekend for R&R. There is also a 20m indoor pool and a well-equipped (and busy) gym. The breakfast restaurant (French Kitchen) has got a terrace so if the season is right you can sit outside and enjoy the Tokyo morning whilst enjoying coffee and croissant. A very stylish hotel, great location, no exaggerated "airs n graces" that you might get at the Mandarin, and my first choice in Tokyo for years now.

reviews.text: My wife and I stayed for one night on a Saturday after I had a work-related conference elsewhere in Tokyo. It was a great experience. The hotel is integrated with the Ropponggi Hills complex, which gives you lots to do for a short stay. The rooms were beautifully designed, with wonderful touches in terms of both form and function. Wonderful bathrooms with rainshowers.

reviews.title: Good location for restaurants, shopping and night life
reviews.text: As one person noted, the fact that you have to pay to use the pool (but not the gym) is a little bit annoying, but really you're not going to fight about it if you are staying at the Grand Hyatt already. If I really had a gripe (and it would be incredibly hard to find) it would be that the hotel could have been better integrated into the mall where there was a clearly labeled way you could get from your room to the mall. We discovered that by going to the 6th floor, we could walk over to another elevator that would then take us down into the mall, right to L'Atelier by Robuchon, which was a delightful dining experience (and also a wonderful place to get breakfast pastries instead of going downstairs).

reviews.title: Almost fab
reviews.text: Two thumbs up. Great experience.

reviews.title: If hotels could all be like this
reviews.text: Stayed at the Grand Hyatt this past March. The hotel is a high rise in an area convenient to restaurants, shopping and night life. There is no central business district per-se in Tokyo. There are areas all over the city like this one, that are business centers, but not just a main one like in most cities. You can really see this, when you go next door to the hotel, where they have a mall and on top of that building an observatory/area where you can see the whole city at your feet. We had booked a room in the concierge floor and was smallish but confortable with an amazing bathroom. A gigantic open shower, with a groove for drainage in between the shower and the equally huge tub. Separate toilet that serves other purposes as well. All very interesting. Tried their subway system on a holiday and Saturday (wouldn't go on a regular work day) and it's quite an experience. People were so nice, they come and try to help you even when you don't ask, as the number of available lines and the areas they cover are overwhelming. All types of restaurants around the area, from sushi places, to TGIF, to a Brazilian (very close to the hotel, which I wouldn't recommend at all as the service stinks), and clubs. Try a typical Japanese Steak House, it's quite an experience. Once you choose your steak, which they bring to your table, they'll provide you with raw samples of the chosen steaks for your approval. Wanted to pay extra for a late check-out of the hotel ,but was allowed to stay only until 3PM (our flight out of Tokyo was at 10 PM) for a percentage of the room rate. Oh well.

reviews.title: Stay here if it's convenient
reviews.text: What wasn't described is that this hotel is located in very much a business district. Not the type of hotel where you can just walk out the door to shop and eat. That said, you must take a taxi everywhere to depart, or walk (15 minutes) to the nearest train station. Also interesting to note: the restaurant/club on the top floor has views to die for, but beware that to sit in the bar only there is a cover charge even if you eat and drink there. And very, very pricey. We ordered one piece of cheese cake, one glass of wine and a hot tea and the price with the cover was $80.00.

reviews.text: A great hotel. All the previous reviews capture it. Tokyo is a large city so just be mindful of where the hotel is located vs. where you plan on spending most of your time.

reviews.title: So Modern!
reviews.text: Stayed 5 nights at the Grand Hyatt on a recent trip to Tokyo. It's in a good, convenient location near Roppongi Hills and we found it only a short cab ride to other places like Omote-Sando or Shibuya. We had a room on the 9th floor (no exciting view, sadly) & whilst the room had everything you could need we found it to be lacking in atmosphere. I guess perhaps that's what you expect from a chain hotel, but we really could have been in New York or Paris or whatever - would have been nice for the hotel to have had more of a Japanese feel. If I travelled again I'd probably not choose to stay here though if you're travelling on business or like chain-type hotels it's a good choice. Personally I'll be looking instead for a more boutique style hotel which feels more Japanese. Some of the hotel restaurants are good though - the new Teppanayki one is great (if expensive), and there's a jazz bar (can't remember the name) which is also worth a visit. Staff very friendly and efficient.

The Grand Hyatt Tokyo combines everything you'd need for your business stay. It has fantastic rooms (although you could spend 10-15 minutes trying to figure out all the knobs and still don't know how to turn the lights on) and its restaurants are amazing. Its location in the Roppongi Hills complex is an added bonus to those who want the convenience of shopping and even more restaurants from which to choose. The only downside is that there is practically no view other than the office buildings next door. The gym and pool is adequate though not amazing. The staff is always very helpful and often go out of their way to help you.
